segments.text: Well, that I wanted to get where the action was and where I was needed and where I was trained to be.
I hadn't trained to be in the State Department down in South America where the war going on worldwide and all my friends on the way.
Did you put in for a transfer?
Well, that was almost every day, every opportunity I had.
I'd been doing that for a long time.
They were, the War Department was insistent that I stay where I was.
And the Chief of Staff of the Air Force was asking for me every chance he got.
He finally got me, but it took a long time.
Once you get
Air Force officer got detached and with another department.
That was free to that department, you see.
Sure.
It's hell to get them out.
Real hard to get them out.
Were you happy to leave Costa Rica and go to Miami Beach in 1942, even though you were still in the American Intelligence Command?
Well, actually I had to leave Panama.
You see, when I was relieved in Colombia, finally I was assigned to that intelligence office in Panama, Canal Zone.
And I got relieved from there and went to Miami Beach.
And yes, I was.
Not that I was happy about the intelligence command, but I got closer back where I could start doing something by getting back in the airport.
That's what I wanted to do.
Now what is, what was your job as Air Officer, American Intelligence Command?
Well, American Intelligence Command was a command that was set up to provide intelligence of the North and South American continents.
Geographic kind of division of responsibility for collection, evaluation, and what not.
And my job there was to head the air section
of that and collect and evaluate and report intelligence information for the North and South American continent area into the head G2 office in Pentagon.
Why do they have a qualified pilot of bombers do a job like that?
Why didn't they have another Air Force officer, like a navigator or someone like that?
Why a pilot?
There are ways and ways to look at that, of course.
And if you have someone who is evaluating air information,
you will take or assume a qualification of a pilot officer before you would of a non-pilot officer.
That's natural.
I certainly would.
So if you can afford the luxury of having a pilot in that job, you're going to have him in here.
If you can't, you just settle for what's next best.
and they were able to hold me for it for a while.
And did they give you a promotion?
Yes, I was promoted as long as I was already way behind at that time.
I can't say that this command kept me behind.
I was just behind because I wasn't in the Air Force doing things that warranted promotion.
But I was promoted, I believe, to major within that command.
I'm sure that's right, yeah.
And how many men under your command?
Well, not really a very good measure of the job.
There were probably...
300 in that order, but there's scattered detachments all over the whole western hemisphere.
And most of them were reporting rather than acting under command.
They were
under command insofar as the function of reporting information is concerned.
But someone else, their parent command was charged with providing the other things that one provides on command, food and shelter and transportation and all these kind of things.
So this is much more like a staff job than it is a command job.
And you must have worked directly with the Army and the Navy
Yes, they're in the same building for this command.
The whole thing there was under, well it was under army officer at that time.
And is this sort of a predecessor to the DIA?
Well, yes, except DIA of course is worldwide.
No, I wouldn't say that.
Were you in the OSS?
I mean, was it part of that?
No, no.
No, it was part of the Army Air Force intelligence.
DIA developed later out of other considerations.
This was just an administrative way of handling information at that time by G-2.
of the Army.
I don't think it had any real long-range significance at all.
It was just a way of getting it done at that time.
Were there major problems that you had?
Were there certain things that you were looking for?
Well, every day of course there are those things, and they change almost every day.
Not quite,
Subversion of local governments was one of the big problems.
German-Italian influence of various activities that went on in the Western Hemisphere.
And of course information on German submarines was just every minute of every day and night.
There were many things they were looking for, yes.
Did you spot German submarines?
Oh yes, many of them.
Oh yes, we did.
We were instrumental in getting a lot of them sunk.
Now were there certain governments in South and Central America or in the Caribbean that you were more concerned about coming under German or Italian influence than others?
Oh, yeah.
What were those?
Well, even at this late date, I think it's probably not good to discuss that very much.
Some are well known, but some aren't.
Columbia
had some wonderful people in its government, but there were lots of people who weakened what that government could do, how effective it was.
It was strongly pro-Axis.
To a greater or lesser degree, there were others.
It's probably not too good to talk about that one very much, even now.
Okay.
In 1943, July of 43, you left.
You were eager to leave, I bet.
Yes.
In May of 43, I got my orders to the Second Air Force.
That was headquarters in Spokane, Washington.
commanded by a man named Johnson, for whom I had worked at Hamilton Field, and he knew me.
So, when he heard I was coming back, he assigned me to command a group of B-24s to go to North Africa as fast as I could train them and get them out of there.
he had a chief of staff named Nathan Bedford Forrest.
And when he saw that I had been out of the States for about seven years, and hadn't done my tour of duty as training in the United States, training others,
He couldn't stand to see me pick up a group and go to North Africa.
He thought I ought to do my stint here first.
So while I was en route from Spokane to Tucson, where the group was to be, he changed my order.
Ordered me to take over the training group, and the guy who had the training group to take my group.
and put it together and go to North Africa, which we did.
Meantime, when I got the training group started, the wing of which we were a part, I think had seventeen groups in it.
were in bad need of an operations officer.
And the man who was commanding it knew me and knew my experience.
And so he relieved me of the training group and made me the wing operations officer.
I was the wing operations officer about three weeks when I got a wire from the chief of staff's office in Washington ordering me to India.
So my wife and family had just joined me there, and we moved into a house in Tucson because there were no quarters available.
So I went home
told my wife what to do about getting my bag together in the afternoon.
I worked that night and got home early the next morning.
I got on the airplane for India that afternoon about one o'clock and didn't get back for about thirty months.
What were your thoughts on going to India?
It was going to war.
I was just as happy
Was it India or anyplace else?
That doesn't bother me.
I'll find out what there was in India.
General Stratmire had asked for me.
That's all I wanted to know.
General Strat was a group commander of the 7th Bomb Group back at Hamilton Field and
I was his pilot and his operations officer there as a second lieutenant.
He hadn't seen me since that time, but he knew what I could do.
So he wanted me in India.
So he promoted me to colonel and put me on the airplane and we went to New Delhi, the next stop.
And when did you arrive in New Delhi?
Late July, July 25th as I remember, late July of 43.
He assigned me there as assistant to the Deputy Chief of Staff Operations for Air Force's CBI, China India Burma Theater.
And I worked at that job until I got to know India and know what was there and what the British capability was and what we could do, learn my way around.
What was the British capability?
Well, the British had some air forces there, mainly Indian air units that were manned by Indians.
And it was practically negligible, not very much.
And we didn't have very much either.
We had the 10th Air Force there, which had the 7th Bomb Group, the same group I had back in Hamilton Field, the same group I was in.
And a couple of fighter units.
That's all they had.
The 14th Air Force, of course, in China with Chennault, which wasn't under that headquarters yet at that time.
I went on and worked in that job, and we got orders from Washington to work out a plan for bringing to bear the B-29s on Japan.
And so for the next almost a month, my assistant and I, a man named Mean, generated the plan to base the B-29s in India
through Chengdu and China and hit Japan and staged back through Chengdu to India for Beijing.
And that was day and night around the clock in the war room until we got it finished and handed it to the guy to take to Washington.
Well, they approved it later and then we had to implement it, so we got busy about that.
And how many bomb runs did we have using that run?
Oh, quite a lot.
Yeah, I don't remember now.
They probably went on around 20 missions, and there were three squadrons of B-29s.
There'd be like 50 at a mission.
So there was some very substantial effort before we got through it.
And is it from this area that we did a lot of the firebombs?
Yes, they did a great deal of it, a very great deal of it.
Much of that though came from Saipan, came from the other way after they captured Saipan.
Amen.
We considered the firebombs not an adequate payload.
The things that we needed, thought needed damaging, we couldn't do it with firebombs.
Heavy submarine installations and heavy revetments and stuff, we were after.
And did you do any of the bombing in China itself against Japanese forces in the Manchuria area or in North China?
Not with the B-29.
We operated against them all the time with the B-24, B-25, all of the fighter and fighter bomber airplanes.
We operated all the time against them there.
Now did you yourself get out of headquarters and get to do some flying?
Some.
I got to do some flying, but very little combat flying.
As a matter of fact, the old man prohibited me from doing any of it.
I did get on one good long mission, but that was all.
And where was that to?
out of eastern India across Burma into Thailand.
Attacked against Japanese aircraft at what is now Bangkok, outside of Bangkok.
And you were attacking the base?
Yeah.
Was it a fighter or bomber base?
Aircraft on the base.
There were a few Bettys, but they were mostly zero, mostly fighter.
Or was it a low level of time?
Yeah, right in the deck.
In the middle of the day?
Right on the deck.
Oh, right on the deck.
But was it at dawn?
No, it was about the middle of the day, as a matter of fact.
Just about the middle of the day, 11 o'clock, I guess.
How successful was it?
Very.
We got what we went for.
I don't remember the statistics on it, but we wiped out the airplanes that were on the field.
They were so complacent, the Japanese, because they didn't think we could reach them.
And if we hadn't have gotten the new P-51s, well we couldn't have, but they didn't know we got them.
So we reached them.
Got it.
And what were you flying?
That's all they wanted.
on that mission.
Why did the commander let you go on that mission?
Well, he didn't have much choice.
I told him to.
That was pretty much the only combat mission that he let you go?
Yeah, that's right.
I was along on a lot of others, but I wasn't doing the job.
Okay, so you were observing on the others?
Well, yes and no.

When Mountbatten came over to assume command, one of the things that he had to do to get his house in order was to go over to China and call on Chiang Kai-shek, which is a job I think he didn't relish too much.
But he asked Donald Stratt and some others to go on the trip.
I was one of them.
We went out of New Delhi and went into Assam, which is on the India side of the hump.
What I wanted to do was to fly over the hump into Kunming and then change airplanes and go to Chongqing, because the only thing that could land at Chongqing was a DC-3.
bomber or anything like that up here in the mountains.
So we went over the hump and went into Kunming and changed to DC-3 and went on up to Chongqing and had our two days of conversations with Chiang and his people and headed back.
but took off out of Kunming one morning about a little bit before sunup, just a little bit before.
General Stratt was in the airplane and I was flying it.
I had a copilot and the surgeon was in there and the rest were crew, tail gunner and turret gunner and ball gunner and nose gunner.
It was a beautiful morning over the hump.
It was just one little thin layer of clouds, about 18,000 feet.
Nice Sunday morning, everybody quiet.
They were cruising along just above this layer of clouds, and this top turret gunner
reported a zero at 9 o'clock, and I looked.
Just in time to see him duck back into this little thin layer of clouds.
He just popped up like that and ducked back right off the wing tail, but quite a ways off.
So I opened the throttles a little bit to get a little more speed.
Told General Stratton what was happening.
The aircraft had been modified so that people could sit in it in the area where it would normally be occupied by the bomb bay or by part of the bomb bay.
I placed the top turret up here with the bottom under it open and that's where the seats would be.
when General Stratton stood up, he stood on the edge and looked through the door over my shoulder into the cockpit.
The surgeon who was sitting by him, alongside of him, didn't move, he just stayed there.
He didn't know, he wasn't plugged in so he didn't know what was happening.
And the doctor had gone to report him again
and only about half as far out.
And so I bent the straddles a little bit more to get a little more speed, and just the less time it takes to say that, the top turret gun started going off.
He started shooting at them.
Yeah, because he had popped over and came up right on the tail.
he was firing at us, although none of them on that blast hit us.
But they, well these two twin 50s went off in this turret up here.
The red-hot 50 caliber shells started falling out of that thing like this right down everybody's lap down in the path here.
and we were on oxygen.
So, this surgeon reached over first thing, picked one of these up, of course, and put it down there in a white heat.
I don't know why he did it.
And then he recognized what was going on.
By that time, the zero had popped up again, and he put a string of bullet holes right through the wing section of that airplane at that time.
And the tail gunner started hollering, I got him, I got him.
And he did.
He shot him down on that path.
I looked back there, and the surgeon was just as white as a goddamn sheet.
And he was still rubbing his throat and didn't have his oxygen mask on.
I asked him a few minutes, what the hell happened?
What's the matter with you?
And he said, hell, I swallowed my oxygen mask.
I had to pull it back up.
Oh boy, he was really a scared man when he found out what was happening there.
But they got the airplane, we flew on across the hump, nothing further in the way and went on home.
You must have been fairly heavily armed then.
What did you have, three .50 caliber mounts on that?
Four.

I had the top gun, the one I was talking about there, then you had the tail gun all the way back in the back, and then the ball turret, which is in the bottom, and then the nose turret, all with twin 50s, you see.
So you had a heck of a lot more on them than that Jebs?
Yeah, he's crazy.
Well, I won't say that.
He didn't use very good judgment on it, at least.
Because he was bound to get it.
But I didn't have very many experiences to write about during the war, combat experiences during the war.
That was a different kind of experience to me.
Now, let's talk about how you got along with the Indians.
people, and what was it like living there?
Well, perhaps I can do better by talking about what I did there, because you didn't have very much contact with the Indians, to be true.
When we finished this plan for the basing of the B-29s, and that was almost in isolation, you see, we were just locked up all the time while we were doing that, and going
every hour of 24 hours that you could stand on your feet.
We got that finished, and that was the time that the Sexton Conference was coming up, the conference in Cairo.
And, you know, Stratton wanted me to go to that conference as the air planner for him.
as well as to work with Chenault and Mountbatten.
And Shanks, that's a new Shanks.
So I went with them.
So you went to the Cairo conference?
Yeah.
I've forgotten how long I was there, but it was about ten days, and a few more days, ten I guess.
And I worked with all those people while I was there, as well as our own people from Washington, General Marshall, General Arnold, General Handy, General Kuehler, and all the others that were there.
So it was a most interesting
most interesting time.
And that, as you know, was the time when the final decisions really were made as to how this war was going to be won.
And they went out from there and did it that way.
I mean there were minor changes, but not really significant changes.
So it was the starting point of really the strategy that ended the war.
It was a very important conference.
I did not go up to Tehran with him to see Joe Stalin.
I wished I could have, but I wasn't that high up.
And now as the air planner, what was your function there?
To talk with Hap Arnold and to discuss the problems or what?
Well, every plan that anybody presents, and see this was a combined chiefs of staff.
Yeah, right.
They have an immediate.
You have to have an air plan along with it, whatever it happens to be.
And Mountbatten was full of plans.
And so I had to put the air section of his plans together, as he presented, and then answer questions that were raised about the facts of the matter.
How many airplanes has he got?
What can they do?
This kind of question.
And so I did that for Mountbatten, Chennault, and General Stratton.
and worked with the other planners from all of those commands in helping getting their presentations ready.
It was a very interesting time in another respect.
I spent, I lived with General Chennault in downtown Cairo.
The British had taken over the houses and

assigned people to them and they assigned people to the houses to do the cooking and taking care of things which you have to do in a situation like that for security reasons as well as logistic reasons but sometimes we could be through with our work out at the main house so
And the combined chief's going to be considered another problem that didn't leave us around there.
We'd get the hell out of there and go home.
I listened to Johnson off for two days from like 3 o'clock in the afternoon until too tired to stay up any longer at night, telling me the story of the wandering Jew.
And I don't think he repeated an incident or a lie.
It took him that long.
That man's knowledge of history was something that I'll marvel at as long as I live.
Then he was good.
Can you describe Chenault for me?
He was a
had been described as a wild man of all kinds of things.
He was actually a very careful, thoughtful man who felt that with proper training and equipment that Americans could exceed in any kind of air fighting.
Could excel on that rather than
And he was a tactician in terms of developing tactics for a particular attack, making that separate from strategy.
And he was a very good, very accomplished fighter pilot.
I mean, a fighter jockey, if you want to call him that.
he could make his airplane do what he wanted it to do, and when he wanted it to do it.
Therefore, not many people whipped him in the air.
And he taught his people in such a way that this held for them.
And with the AVGs, why, he proved it to the world.
Because the P-40 was certainly no match for the Zero.
But it shot down a lot of Zeros just the same.

he had the confidence of a lot of people, including Chiang Kai-shek and Madame Chiang, and the support of a lot of Chinese officers, and therefore a very great deal of influence on whatever military operations would take place in China.
Generally this was good.
I don't mean it as something bad, but I think of him as a very wise, kind, compassionate man.
A real fine American.
You were a colonel at the time.
How did the general get along with his subordinates?
John Chenault?
Wonderful.
Wonderful.
Every one of them respected him very much.
Many of them idolized him.
By the time I'm talking about, they'd all been decommissioned and they were civilians, you see.
while we were there that we got them reinstated later on so that they became officers again in the Air Force.
But he had the full support of his subordinates and always has any job he's ever had.
It's his superiors that he hasn't gotten along with so well.
He's a little bit impatient with them and he had some
some peers that are pretty damn hard to get along with themselves.
Example, Stilwell.
Did you get to know General Stilwell?
Oh, yeah.
I got to know him well enough.
Could you describe him?
Well, I'd be a little bit biased, because when he found out I had been recommended for promotion to Breeder General, he wired John Marshall not to do it.
No kidding.
Why was that?
it came out to be something silly.
I had written a plan in my planning headquarters there in New Delhi to win the war in CBR.
Nothing strange about that.
One of my responsibilities was planning, so we did it.
And for the purposes of this plan, we made an air theater out of the
theater and won the war in the air by air power.
And in doing that we had an air officer as theater commander which seemed perfectly natural to me.
when the air planner, General Keeler, who was A-5 of the air staff back here in Washington, came through China, or through India, I told him about that.
And he said, let me have a copy of it.
Well, I didn't think a damn thing about it.
I gave him a copy of it.
He was the head planner for the Air Force,
And he read it on the way home from CBI.
And when he got back there, he liked it.
And he gave it to General Handy.
And General Handy was the G3 of the Army.
In other words, General Marshall, the planner.
And General Handy read the plan, which flattered me very much that he'd even read it.
But he liked it.
And so he started talking to General Marshall about it.
Well, when Stilwell found out that I had released the plan, which was just a draft in my office, without clearing it through him, and he didn't know a damn thing about it, he hit the ceiling.
And that's when he sent to work.
He called my boss, John Stratt, out of bed at 3 o'clock in the morning.
I called him all the way down into the middle of Calcutta to chew him out about letting me send this thing in, letting me release that plant.
He caught it on a strap flat footed because he didn't know anything about it either.
I hadn't shown it to him or anybody else.
And it wasn't an attempt to get by with the thing.
It's just that I had finished it and I was telling him about it.

matter of fact and started off I was telling Kuehler about what the problem was and said it could be solved by this method and he said why don't you write such a plan and I said well I have and that's when he said well let me have it.
So it was much ado about nothing but it damn near cost me my promotion just to say.
Well, without being intent to be disrespectful, I think he was a good battalion commander.

However, I think he was a real fighting soldier and all that, but he didn't have any business with a command as big as a theater, because he didn't know how to handle people and he didn't know what, he just knew how to hate the British.
That's about the biggest thing.
You thought the job was over his head?
Sure did.
You had an opportunity to meet Shankai Shah.
And what did you think of that, ma'am?
Well, that's a real hard one.
I love the Gothic.
In what way?
And his sincerity and his helplessness in a way.
He wanted to do the right thing.
He never could get enough people to go with him at the same time to quite swing it.
and yet that makes him sound like an angel of some kind.
I don't mean that at all.
I thought he was a great guy.
He just had a bear by the tail that I don't know whether anybody could have handled or not.
He certainly had the strength of his convictions, or he wouldn't have done all the things he did, including go to Taiwan.
But the U.S. let him down very much.
And you can find, of course, a lot of people tell you lots of stories about why that was good and why it was warranted and all that.
I still think it's a bunch of baloney.
We moved the armies of Chiang into North China to take over from the communists and did.
And it was a real operation.
We moved nearly 200,000 troops by air, an average of over 1,000 miles in order to do that on the tail end of a pipeline for gasoline.
And then the United States let the troops sit there and starve to death, while the Communists took them over.
I shouldn't say it quite that way.
I think we had the capacity to have kept him in the driver's seat if we wanted to, and we didn't.
Did you ever have any conversations with him?
Oh yeah, yes.
About what types of topics?
Several things, everything, every kind of problem.
I had conversations with him about military problems, specific things that we dealt on not a day-to-day basis but a week-to-week basis with him.
But conversations about lots of other things too outside the military.
Do you remember any of those conversations?
Pardon?
Do you remember some of those conversations?
And his attitudes?
Yes, his attitude was one of fun and wholesomeness in the things that I talked with him about.
After Pekin fell, a group of us, including General Strath and myself,
went to Peking and had lunch with Chang and Madame Chang in the Summer Palace in Peking, and I was seated next to him for lunch.
Lunch of that kind lasts about three hours, and if you don't have some
lady standing behind you to drink your hot rice wine, you won't know the end of the three hours comes anyway.
So we talked about everything under the sun, I know more.
I enjoyed talking to him very much.
I don't remember specifically the subjects we talked about.
What about the charges that he was corrupt?
Well, I think anybody who survives in China at that time, probably not true for them,
had to do some things that our people would call corrupt.
And maybe some of them were, I don't know.
His aim was not corruption.
His aim was to get away from that.
To be able to have a government and run a government without corruption.
But you can't go from a situation by a wish to a fact.
And of course there was corruption in the government, some of which I'm sure he must have had some knowledge of.
But I don't think he was a party to, a direct party to.
